channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [MAHOUT-1112] Migrate code from Lucene / Solr 3.6 to 4.0.0
item.description:
Lucene/Solr 4.0.0 was released on October 12, 2012

Many of the functionalities have changed, so it wasn't an easy migration.

I'm including a patch, which passes all junit tests, for review.
item.summary: Migrate code from Lucene / Solr 3.6 to 4.0.0

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: This patch is a better patch for that individual file. Was a bit confused about using null as the idfield, but after reading some doc it seems its the right way to go

First glance this looks good. I noticed the SlowComposite reader stuff in there. We probably should find a way to not have to use that, but for now it is probably fine (plus I need to brush up on those things, too)

i hear ya, i believe i only used it in ClusterLabels, though i'd be very open to suggestions : )

i found that the problem was that the function isDeleted was removed, making iteration over all documents a difficult since you don't know if it is or isn't there.

the AtomicReader assures a snapshot view of the repository at reader creation time, so that problem is circumvented.

i didn't really see any special note in the migration text about how to deal with this issue, but looking back i think i have a few ideas.

if its a problem, create me a ticket and i'll implement my ideas there in a patch while you review this one. for the time being i think it should be okay to at least get things rolling.

fyi the approach i'm thinking may also work is:

  Bits liveDocs = MultiFields.getLiveDocs(indexReader);
  if (liveDocs.get(docID)) {
    // document is not deleted...
  }

but haven't had time to test it
What is the point of the javaee-api dependency? I don't see any code in mahout-lucene-3.6-to-4.0.0-patch

good question.

i found the dependency need via a google search:

http://www.andrejkoelewijn.com/wp/2010/03/04/absent-code-attribute-in-method-that-is-not-native-or-abstract/

had the problem, applied the solution, problem went away

of course if its not a reproducible issue, feel free to remove it. as you noted, there is no explicit coding need for it via the work i've submitted

i found the dependency need via a google search:
http://www.andrejkoelewijn.com/wp/2010/03/04/absent-code-attribute-in-method-that-is-not-native-or-abstract/

That is very peculiar.

That posting is talking about the solution being to remove the dependency. You have added the dependency. Very odd.

As per my comment above, find attached a version of ClusterLabel which doesn't use an AtomicReader or SlowCompositeReader.

There is also a resolved bug that minNumIds/maxLabels was always overridden with the default value even if given at command line.

Submitting a patch (v2) with all the previous ones rolled into one, plus corrected a bug in LuceneIterator.

Also removed the javaee-api dependency. seems that my repo was a bit corrupt, removing it removed the need for the dependency.

thinking about it a bit more i wonder, has mahout considered matching its release versions with lucene like solr has recently? thus mahout 4.0 will work with solr/lucene 4.0, obviating the need for a compatibility matrix?

Hadoop is in the mix as well.

Sent from my iPhone

thus mahout 4.0 will work with solr/lucene 4.0

Good idea, but we're still working on 1.0, never mind 4.0

Starting to review, seems like we could put together a few utility classes to reduce the amount of repeated code (which was in there before), i.e.:

if (analyzerName.equals(StandardAnalyzer.class.getName())) {
            Class<?>[] params = new Class<?>[1];
            params[0] = Version.class;
            Object[] args = new Object[1];
            args[0] = Version.LUCENE_40;

            analyzer = ClassUtils.instantiateAs(context.getConfiguration().get(DocumentProcessor.ANALYZER_CLASS,
                    StandardAnalyzer.class.getName()),
                    Analyzer.class, params, args);

        } else {
            analyzer = ClassUtils.instantiateAs(analyzerName, Analyzer.class);
        }

I see code like that in a few places. Maybe an AnalyzerUtils?

I'll try to get to it next week, but if you want to go for it Andrew, that would be great.

We also seem to have some inconsistent usage around creating analyzers. In some cases, we check if it is StdAnalyzer, in other places we don't.

Also, a quick scan of most analyzers in 4 indicate they take in Version, etc. We probably should figure out some better way to instantiate Analyzers.

User feedback, FWIW:
I've been using the patch for a few weeks with zero problems. Specifically utils.vector.lucene.Driver.dumpVectors() works fine, and I'm using a custom analyzer and tokenizer, no problems there.

I had to edit the patch locally (but only integration/pom.xml, nothing major) before applying because I had pulled revisions past this patch.

Megan,

Thanks so much for the feedback.
Megan, Glad to be of service : )
I'll take a look. I suppose we might as well go to 4.1 at this point, which this patch should be able to handle pretty easily.
still running tests, but here's a bit of a cleaned up version and I pushed it to 4.1 of Lucene.
Here's an updated patch that properly handles token streams in a number of places. I think I have on nocommit left, where I need to go dig into TermEnum a bit more.
Need to run the tests one last time. Megan Galloway, Andrew Janowczyk, can you check out this patch and confirm it works for you? Assuming the tests pass and you give the thumbs up, I will commit.
All tests pass with the latest patch. I will commit tomorrow AM eastern time.
Patch applied with no problems, and my application still behaves as expected. Looks good to me. Thanks!
Committed. Thanks Andrew and Megan!

Integrated in Mahout-Quality #1845 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/Mahout-Quality/1845/)
MAHOUT-1112: upgrade to Lucene 4.1.0 (Revision 1440334)

Result = SUCCESS
